characters: SHOT OF A GREEN FOREST WITHOUT RAIN. RESUME
SHOT OF A FOREST, IN GENTLE SPRING RAINFALL. RESUME
SHOT OF EMBERS POURING FROM THE HELLISH FOREST FIRE. RES
SHOT OF THE INSIDE OF JACK'S FROZEN ICE CAVE. RESUME
CLOSE ON THE BASE OF JACK'S REFRIGERATOR
SHOT OF A GREEN MAPLE LEAF, GLISTENING WITH DEW. RESUME
FUR COAT, TURNING HER HEAD TO LOOK TOWARDS US. RESUME
SHOT OF TREES ENGULFED BY A FOREST FIRE. RESUME
SHOT OF INSIDE THE ICE CAVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TYLER has one arm around Jack's shoulder; the other hand holds a HANDGUN with the barrel lodged in JACK'S MOUTH. Tyler is sitting in Jack's lap. They are both sweating and disheveled, both around 30; Ty is blond, handsome; and Jack, brunette, is appealing in a dry sort of way.  Tyler looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One minute. (looking out window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the beginning.  We're at ground zero.  Maybe you should say a few words, to mark the occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... i... ann....iinn.. ff....nnyin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a gun barrel between your teeth, you only speak in vowels. Jack tongues the barrel to the side of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still distorted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't think of anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With my tongue, I can feel the rifling in the barrel.  For a second, I totally forgot about Tyler's whole controlled demolition thing and I wondered how clean this gun is. Tyler checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting exciting now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That old saying, how you always hurt the one you love, well, it works both way. Jack turns so that he can see down -- 31 STORIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have front row seats for this Theater of Mass Destruction.  The Demolitions Committee of Project Mayhem wrapped the foundation columns of ten buildings with blasting gelatin.  In two minutes, primary charges will blow base charges, and those buildings will be reduced to smoldering rubble.  I know this because Tyler knows this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what we've accomplised. (checks watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow, I realize all of this -- the gun, the bombs, the revolution -- is really about Marla Singer. PULL BACK from Jack's face.  It's pressed against TWO LAR BREASTS that belong to...BOB, 45, a moose of a man.  Jack engulfed by Bob in an intense embrace.  Bob weeps openly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob had bitch tits. PULL BACK to wide on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men are paired off, hugging, talking in emotional tones. Near the door, a SIGN on a stand: "REMAINING MEN TOGETHER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was a support group for men with testicular cancer.  The big moosie slobbering all over me was Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're still men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  We're men.  Men is what we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six months ago, Bob's testicles were removed.  Then hormone therapy.  He developed bitch tits because his testosterone was too high and his body upped the estrogen.  That was where my head fit -- into his huge, sweating tits that hung enormous, the way we think of God's as big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're gonna have to open my pec's again to drain the fluid. Bob hugs tighter; then looks with empathy into Jack's eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  You cry now. Jack looks at Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.  Back up.  Let me start earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack lies in bed, staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For six months.  I could not sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, sleepy, stands over a copy machine.  His Starbucks sits on the lid, moving back and forth as the machine cop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With insomnia, nothing is real. Everything is far away.  Everything is a copy of a copy of a copy. Other people make copies, all with Starbucks cups, sippin Jack picks up his cup and his copies and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, sipping, stares blankly at a Starbucks bag on the floor, full of newspapers and FAST FOOD GARBAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When deep space exploration ramps up, it will be corporations that name everything.  The IBM Stellar Sphere. The Philip Morris Galaxy.  Planet Starbucks. Jack looks up as a pudgy man, Jack's BOSS, enters, Starbu cup in hand, and slides a stack of reports on Jack's desk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to need you out-of-town a little more this week.  We've got some "red-flags" to cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must've been Tuesday.  he was wearing his "cornflower-blue" tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listless management speak)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to de-prioritize my current reports until you advise of a status upgrade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to make these your primary "action items."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was full of pep.  Must've had his grande latte enema.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here are your flight coupons.  Call me from the road if there are any snags.  Your itinerary... Jack hides a yawn, pretends to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits on the toilet, CORDLESS PHONE to his ear, flips through an IKEA catalog.  There's a stack of old Playboy magazines and other catalogs nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like everyone else, I had become a slave to the IKEA nesting instinct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I'd like to order the Erika Pekkari slip covers. Jack drops the open catalog on the floor. MOVE IN ON CATALOG -- ON PHOTO of COFFEETABLE SET...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I saw something like clever coffee table sin the shape of a yin and yang, I had to have it. PAN TO PHOTO of ARMCHAIR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the Johanneshov armchair in the Strinne green stripe pattern...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The armchair APPEARS.  PAN OVER next to armchair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the Rislampa wire lamps of environmentally-friendly unbleached paper. The lamps APPEAR.  PAN OVER to wall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even the Vild hall clock of galvanized steel, resting on the Klipsk shelving unit. The clock APPEARS as the shelving unit APPEARS on the wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would flip through catalogs and wonder, "What kind of dining set defines me as a person?"  We used to read pornography.  Now it was the Horchow Collection. A dining room set APPEARS.  Jack, the cordless phone stil glued to his ear, walks INTO FRAME and continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't want Cobalt.  Oh, that sounds nice.  Apricot. Jack opens a cabinet, takes out a plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had it all.  Even the glass dishes with tiny bubbles and imperfections, proof they were crafted by the honest, simple, hard-working indigenous peoples of wherever. He rummages through the refrigerator.  It's practically empty.  Jack takes out a jar of mustard, opens it and use a butter knife to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, eyes puffy, face pale, sits before an INTERN, who studies him with bemusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you can't die of insomnia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I died already.  Look at my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to lighten up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you give me something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red-and-blue Tuinal, lipstick-red Seconals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping w/ above)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need healthy, natural sleep. Chew valerian root and get some more exercise. The Intern ushes Jack to the door.  They step into the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Intern walks away from Jack, picks up a chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (facetious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see pain?  Swing by First Methodist Tuesday nights.  See the guys with testicular cancer.  That's pain. The Intern moves into the other room.  Jack stares after

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack heads for the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stares at a group of men, including Bob, who are all listening to a group member speak at a lectern.  The SPEA has pale skin and sunken eyes -- he's clearly dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... wanted three kids.  Two boys and a girl.  Mindy wanted two girls and one boy.  We never could agree on anything. The Speaker cracks a sad smile.  Some men chuckle, happy lighten the mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she had her first child a month ago, a girl, with her new husband... And, Thank God.  I'm glad for her, because she deserves... The speaker breaks down, WEEPS UNCONTROLLABLY. Jack watches.  A couple of the men go up to the speaker, comforting him, leading him away.  A LEADER takes the sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone, let's thank Thomas for sharing himself with us. Jack, uncomfortable, joins EVERYONE ELSE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look around this room and I see a lot of courage.  And it gives me strength.  We give each other strength. Jack looks around.  Many of the men are sniffling, sobbin Jack squirms in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time for the one-on-one.  Let's follow Thomas's example and open ourselves. Everyone gets out of their chairs and begins pairing-off. Jack stands, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can everyone find a partner? Bob, his chin down on his chest, starts toward Jack, shuffling his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big moosie, his eyes already shrink-wrapped in tears.  Knees together, invisible steps. Bob takes Jack into an embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob was a champion bodybuilder.  You know that chest expansion program you see on TV?  That was his idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...using steroids.  I was a juicer. Diabonol, then, Wisterol -- it's for racehorses, for Christsake.  Now I'm bankrupt, divorced, my two grown kids won't return my calls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strangers with this kind of honesty make me go a big rubbery one. Bob breaks into sobbing, putting his head on Jack's shoul and completely covering Jack's face.  After a long beat o crying, Bob raises up his head, looks at Jack's NAMETAG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Cornelius.  You can cry. They look at each other.  Slowly, Jack's eyes grow wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then... something happened.  I was lost in oblivion -- dark and silent and complete. Bob pulls Jack's head back into his chest.  Jack tightens his arms around Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found freedom.  Losing all hope was freedom. Jack pulls away from Bob.  On Bob's chest, there's a WET MASK of Jack's face from how he looks weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babies don't sleep this well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack lies sound asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I became addicted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack moves into a "group hug" of sickly people, men and women.  In view is a sign by the door "Free and Clear."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands with a weeping middle-aged WOMAN.  He begins cry along with her.  A sign by the door: "Onward and Upwa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I didn't say anything, people assumed the worst.  They cried harder.  I cried harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone, including Jack, sits back in their seats, EYES CLOSED.  The Leader speaks into a microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight, we're going to open the green door -- the heart chakra...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't really dying, I wasn't host to cancer or parasites; I was the warm little center that the life of this world crowded around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And you open the door and you step inside.  We're inside our hearts.  Now, imaging your pain as a white ball of healing light.  That's right, the pain itself is a ball of healing light. Jack, eyes closed, is silent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It moves over your body, healing you. Keep this going and step forward, through the back door of the room. Where does it lead?  To your cave. Step forward into your cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack walks along, moving through an ICE CAVERN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  You're going deeper into your cave.  And you're going to find your power animal... Jack comes upon a PENGUIN.  The penguin looks at him, coc his head to signal Jack forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slide. The penguin jumps onto a patch of ICE and slides away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack walks out a doorway, saying goodbye to people.  He walks down the sidewalk, shining with peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every evening I died and every evening I was born again.  Resurrected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's still in an embrace with Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob loved me because he thought my testicles were removed too.  Being there, my face against his tits, ready to cry -- this was my vacation. MARLA SINGER enters.  She has short matte black hair and big, dark eyes like a character from japanese animation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, she ruined everything. Marla looks around, raises a cigarette to her lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is cancer, right? Bob and Jack stare, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone paired-off.  MOVE THROUGH ROOM... FIND JACK'S FA as he stares... MOVE THROUGH ROOM... FIND MARLA'S FACE. She's drinking coffee, smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ... chick ... Marla Singer ... did not have testicular cancer.  She was a liar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla sits with the group, smoking, listening intently wh a member speaks.  Jack spies on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had no diseases at all.  I had seen her at my melanoma Monday night group ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla sits at the end of a row, smoking.  All the faces d the row are turned toward her, incredulous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and at "Free and Clear," my blood parasites group Thursdays. Jack leans out further than the others, scornful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And, again, at "Seize The Day," my tuberculosis Friday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack watches... Marla's eyes are closed, her head on the shoulder of the MAN she's embraced by.  She opens her eye catching Jack's stare.  Jack looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla -- the big tourist.  Her lie reflected my lie. Marla rests her chin on the man's shoulder.  Tears roll d her cheeks.  She wipes at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla walks out,  The support group's dispersing.  Jack exits amongst them.  He spots Marla walking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And suddenly, I felt nothing.  I couldn't cry.  So, once again, I could not sleep. Jack stares after Marla for a long moment.  He walks away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, in underwear, is cross-legged on the floor, assembl IKEA furniture, CORDLESS PHONE shouldered to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I just can't believe that card is declined -- Okay, okay, let me give you a different card number. Jack gets his wallet off the floor, pulls out another car and, MOS over the following, he reads it into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next group, after guided meditation, after we open our chakras, when it's time to hug, I'm going to grab that little bitch, Marla Singer, pin her arms against her sides and say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON JACK as he CLAMPS his arms around Marla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla, you liar, you big tourist.  I need this.  Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, in pajamas, stares at Home Shopping Network on his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you have insomnia, you're never really asleep and you're never really awake.  I hadn't slept in four days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack walks in and joins the crowd, looking around.  Peopl are chattering with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- But, in here, in everyone, there's the squint of a five-day headache. Yet they forced themselves to be positive.  They never said "parasite;" they said "agent."  They always talked about getting better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, everyone. Everyone sits in chairs.  Jack catches sight of Marla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To open tonight's communion, Chloe would like to say a few words. Taking the lectern is CHLOE, a pale, sickly girl whose sk stretches yellowish and tight over her bones.  She wears head bondage.  She clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, Chloe.  Chloe looked the way Joni Mitchell's skeleton would look if you made it smile and walk around a party being extra nice to everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm still here -- but I don't know for how long.  That's as much certainty as anyone can give me.  but I've got some good news -- I no longer have any fear of death. APPLAUSE from around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... I am in a pretty lonely place. No one will have sex with me.  I'm so close to the end and all I want is to get laid for the last time.  I have pornographic movies in my apartment, and lubricants and amyl nitrate ... The LEADER gingerly takes control of the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Chloe.  Everyone, let's thank Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, you're standing at the entrance to your cave.  You step inside your cave and you walk.  Keep walking. Jack's face, eyes closed, is motionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I did have a tumor, I'd name it Marla.  Marla...the little scratch on the roof of your mouth that would heal if only you could stop tonguing it, but you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, find your power animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack finds Marla smoking a cigarette.  Marla cocks her he indicating whe wants him to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's eyes open and turn to Marla, watching her blow smo rings with her eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone stands and mills about, pairing-off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick someone special to you tonight. Jack sees the ghastly spectre of Chloe ambling towards hi He tries to smile.  She smiles with a twisted, dying mout

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Tayler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never gave my real name at support groups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Chloe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've never actually talked. Chloe's eyes are eerily bright with desperation.  Jack, i a sincere attempt at levity, chokes out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look good.  You ... look ... like a pirate. Chloe laughs, a little too much.  Jack squeezes out a lau Then he sees Marla, off by herself.  Someone heads for he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I have to... Jack gives a quick nod to Chloe and darts towards Marla. Chloe watches him go. STAY ON JACK AND MARLA as Jack CLAMPS his arms around her He whispers into her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on to you.  You're a faker.  You aren't dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, in the Sylvia Plath philosophy way, we're all dying.  But you're not dying the way Chloe is dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the other person how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a tourist.  I saw you at melanoma, tuberculosis and testicular cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I saw you practicing this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practicing what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Telling me off.  Is it going as well as you hoped... ? (reads his nametag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... Mr. Taylor."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll expose you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.  I'll expose you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Share yourself completely. Marla puts her head down on Jack's shoulder as if she wer crying.  Jack pulls her head back up.  She deadpans at hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cheaper than a movie, and there's free coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are my groups.  I was here first.  I've been coming for a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year?  How'd you manage that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone who might've noticed either died or recovered and never came back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let yourself cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't know.  I guess... when people think you're dying, they really listen, instead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Instead of just waiting for their turn to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Brief recognition between them, broken as the Leader pass

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quietly, now.  Share with each other. Jack waits till the Leader's out of earshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It becomes an addiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Jack sighs, then pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I can't cry with a faker present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy-stripe a cancer ward.  It's not my problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.  Can't we do something... ? Marla starts out of the room.  Jack follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, the closing prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla gets to the sidewalk, moving quickly along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll split up the week.  You can have lymphoma, tuberculosis and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take tuberculosis.  My smoking doesn't go over at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think testicular cancer should be no contest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, technically, I have more of a right to be there than you.  You still have your balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- am I? Jack follow Marla into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla walks with authority up to an unwatched DRYER.  She takes out clothes, picks out jeans, pants and shirts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the parasites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't have both parasites.  You can take blood parasites --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want brain parasites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  I'll take blood parasites and organic brain dementia --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't have the whole brain!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far, you have four and I only have two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, take blood parasites.  It's yours.  Now we each have three. Marla gathers the chosen garments and heads out past Jack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack follows, bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... left half your clothes. HONK!  Jack starts.  Marla's led him into the street with traffic barreling down. Marla walks on, oblivious as CARS screech to a halt, HORN BLARING.  Jack dashes, following...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla drops the pile of clothes on a counter.  An old CLE sifts through the clothes, begins writing on a pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're selling those? Marla steps down hard on Jack's foot.  He winces in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (for the Clerk to hear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm selling some chothes. The Clerk starts to ring up the assessed amounts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, we each have three -- that's six. What about the seventh day?  I want ascending bowel cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl had done her homework.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want ascending bowel cancer. The Clerk gives a strange look as he hands money to Marla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your favorite, too?  Tried to slip it by me, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll split it.  You get it the first and third Sunday of the month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deal. They shake.  Jack tries to withdraw his hand; Marla holds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like this is goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not make a big thing out of it. She walks to the door, pocketing money, not looking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's this for not making a big thing? Jack watches her go.  A moment, then he follows after...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack hesitates, unsure, then run/walks to catch up to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Marla, should we maybe exchange numbers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case we want to switch nights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose. Jack takes out a business card, writes his number on the back, hands it to her.  She takes the pen, grabs his hand and writes her number on his palm.  She walks into the street, causing more SCREECHING and HONKING.  She turns, holds up the card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't have your name.  Who are you?  Cornelius?  Mr. Taylor?  Dr. Zaius?  Any of the stupid names you give each night? Jack starts to answer, but the traffic noise is too loud. Marla just shakes her head, turns, and keeps moving.  A B moves into view, obscuring her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how I met Marla Singer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane touches down; the cabin BUMPS.  Jack's eyes ope

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wake up at O'Hare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack snaps awake again, looking around, disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wake up at SeaTac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rear of a CRASHED CAR sticks up by the side of the ro Jack stands, marking on a clipboard.  The SUN SETS behind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands at a gate counter.  An ATTENDANT smiles at hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check-in for that flight doesn't begin for another two hours, Sir. Jack looks with blearing eyes at his watch, steps away an looks at an overhanging CLOCK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pacific, Mountain, Central.  Lose an hour, gain an hour.  This is your life, and it's ending one minute at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's eyes snap open as the plane LANDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wake up at Air Harbor International.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands on a conveyor belt, briefcase at his feet.  H watches PEOPLE MOVING PAST on the opposite conveyor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wake up at a different time and in a different place, could you wake up as a different person? Jack misses seeing TYLER on the opposite conveyor belt. They pass each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits next to a BUSINESSMAN.  As they have idle CONVERSATION, we MOVE IN ON Jack's tray.  An ATTENDANT'S HANDS set coffee down with a small container of cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everywhere I travel -- tiny life. Single-serving sugar, single-serving cream, single pat of butter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANDS place a dinner tray down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Microwave Cordon Bleu hobby kit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack brushes his teeth in the MIRROR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shampoo/conditioner combo.  Single- serving mouthwash, tiny bar of soap. Jack picks up an individual, wrapped Q-TIP, looks at it. moves out of the bathroom into...

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROOM
dialogues.text: Jack sits on the bed.  He turns on the TV.  It's tuned to the "Sheraton Channel," shows WAITERS serving people in a large BANQUET ROOM.  Jack stops brushing his teeth, feels something on the bed, lifts it -- a small DINNER MINT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits next to a frumpy WOMAN.  They chat.  Jack turns look at his food, takes a bite.  He turns back and it's.. --a BALD MAN next to him, talking.  Jack takes another bi turns back and it's... --a BUSINESSMAN next to him.  Jack takes another bite, tu back, and it's... --a BUSINESS WOMAN next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people I meet on each flight -- they're single-serving friends. Between take-off and landing, we have our time together, but that's all we get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's eyes snap open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wake up at Logan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A giant corrugated METAL DOOR opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a long enough time line, the survival rate for everyone drops to zero. Two TECHNICIANS lead Jack to the BURNT-OUT SHELL of a WRECKED AUTOMOBILE.  Jack sets down his briefcase, opens and starts to make notes on a CLIPBOARDED FORM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a recall coordinator.  My job is to apply the formula.  It's a story problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's where the infant went through the windshield.  Three points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new car built by my company leaves somewhere traveling at 60 miles per hour.  The rear differential locks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teenager's braces around the backseat ashtray would make a good "anti-smoking" ad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car crashes and burns with everyone trapped inside.  Now: do we initiate a recall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The father must've been huge.  See how the fat burnt into the driver's seat with his polyester shirt?  Very "modern art."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the number of vehicles in the field, (A), and multiply it by the probable rate of failure, (B), then multiply the result by the average out-of-court settlement, (C).  A times B times C equals X...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack is speaking to the BUSINESSWOMAN next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If X is less than the cost of a recall, we don't do one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there a lot of these kinds of accidents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you wouldn't believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Which... car company do you work for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A major one. Turgid silence.  Jack turns to the window.  He sees a PELICAN get SUCKED into the TURBINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time the plane banked too sharply on take-off or landing, I prayed for a crash, or a mid-air collision -- anything. Jack's face remains bland during the following: the plane BUCKLES -- the cabin wobbles.  People panic.  Masks drop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more haircuts.  Nothing matters, not even bad breath. The side of the plane SHEARS OFF!  Screaming PASSENGERS a sucked out into the night air, flying past the quivering wind.  Magazines and other objects fly everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life insurance pays off triple if you die on a business trip. Jack remains in his same position, same bland expression. DING! -- the seatbelt light goes OUT.  Jack SNAPS AWAKE. EVERYTHING IS NORMAL.  Some passengers get out of their seats.  From next to Jack, a VOICE we've heard before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three ways to make napalm. One, mix equal parts of gasoline and frozen orange juice... Jack turns to see TYLER.  Without turned to Jack, Tyler continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two, equal parts gasoline and diet cola.  Three, dissolve kitty-litter in gasoline until the mixture is thick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me? Tyler turns to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how I met --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler Durden. Tyler offers his hand.  Jack takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why they have oxygen masks on planes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, supply oxygen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oxygen gets you high.  In a catastrophic emergency, we're taking giant, panicked breaths... Tyler grabs a safety instruction CARD from the seatback, hands it to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, we become euphoic and docile.  We accept our fate. Tyler points to passive faces on the drawn figures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emergency water landing, 600 miles per hour.  Blank faces -- calm as Hindu cows. Jack laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do, Tyler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean -- for a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  So you can say, "Oh, that's what you do." -- And be a smug little shit about it? Jack laughs.  Tyler reaches under the seat in front of hi and lifts a BRIEFCASE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a kind of sick desperation in your laugh. Jack points to his own briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have the same briefcase. Tyler turns the top of his briefcase toward Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open it. Jack looks at Tyler, then pops the latches and raises the lid to reveal quaintly-wrapped bars of SOAP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soap -- the yardstick of civilization. (reaches in his pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make and sell soap... Tyler hands Jack his card.  "THE PAPER STREET SOAP COMPAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were to add nitric acid to the soap-making process, one would get nitroglycerin.  With enough soap, one could blow up the world, if one were so inclined. Tyler SNAPS the briefcase shut.  Jack stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler, you are by far the most interesting "single-serving" friend I've ever met. Tyler stares back.  Jack, enjoying his own chance to be witty, leans closer to Tyler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, when you travel, everything is small, self-contained--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spork.  I get it.  You're very clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that working out for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Being clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrown)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh... great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it up, then.  Keep it right up. Tyler stands, looks towards the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... As I squeeze past, do I give you the ass or the crotch? Tyler moves to the aisle, his ass toward jack, walks away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are defined by the choices we make. Tyler goes to the curtain dividing First Class, slaps the curtain aside and sits in an empty seat.  Jack watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How I came to live with Tyler is: airlines have this policy about vibrating luggage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Utterly empty of baggage.  No people except for Jack and SECURITY TASK FORCE MAN.  The Security TFM, smirking, hol a receiver to his ear from an official phone on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throwers don't worry about ticking. Modern bombs don't tick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?  "Throwers?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baggage handlers.  But when a suitcase vibrates, the throwers have to call the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My suitcase was vibrating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine time out of ten, it's an electric razor.  But, every once in a while ... (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it's a dildo.  It's airline policy not to imply ownership in the event of a dildo.  We use the indefinite aricle: "A dildo."  Never "Your dildo." Jack sees, through the window, Tyler, at the curb, throwi his briefcase into the back of a shiny, red CONVERTIBLE. Tyler leaps over the door into the driver's seat and PEEL OUT.  jack turns away, looks at the Security TFM. In the background, a HARRIED MAN dashes after Tyler and t convertible, SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Security TFM)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had everything in that bag.  My C.K. shirts... my D.K.N.Y. shoes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, uh huh... yeah? (pause, still on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone SUITCASE sits on the concrete.  SECURITY PERSONNEL keep their distance.  KABOOM!  The suitcase explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Security TFM, shakes his head, hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry. The Security TFM hands Jack a claim form.  Jack snatches disgusted, takes out a pen, starts filling out the form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the industry slang for "Flight Attendant?"  "Air Mattress."

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Along a residential street.  Jack looks ahead, sees a tal grey, bland BUILDING on the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home was a condo on the fifteenth floor of a filing cabinet for widows and young professionals.  The walls were solid concrete.  A foot of concrete is important when your next- door neighbor lets her hearing aid go and has to watch game shows at full volume... The taxi turns a corner and Jack sees the front of the building.  A diffuse CLOUD of SMOKE wafts away from a BLO OUT SECTION of the fifteenth floor.  FIRETRUCKS, POLICE C and a MOB are all crowded around the lobby area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Or when a volcanic blast of debris that used to be your furniture and personal effects blows out your floor- to-ceiling windows and sails flaming into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, gaping at the sight above him, absently gives the Cabbie money.  The taxi pulls away.  Jack starts toward t building.  He pushes through the fray of people, into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOORMAN sees Jack enter, gives a sad smile, shakes hi head.  Jack starts for the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing up there. Jack presses the button.  The Doorman moves next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't go into the unit.  Police orders. The elevator doors open.  Jack hesitates.  The doors clos Jack heads out the lobby doors.  The Doorman follows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack walks past SMOKING, CHARRED DEBRIS -- a flash of ORA from the Yang table, a CLOCK FACE from the hall clock, pa of an arm from the GREEN ARMCHAIR.  His feet CRUNCH glass

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have somebody you can call? Jack comes to his REFRIGERATOR lying on its side.  He reaches down and takes a note: "MARLA --" and a phone number, from under a BANANA MAGNET.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S STOVE
dialogues.text: Hissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police would later tell me that the pilot light might have gone out... letting out just a little bit of gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack gets to a PAYPHONE.  The Doorman follows, watching h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of young people try to impress the world and buy too many things. Jack picks up the receiver, puts in a quarter.  He looks Marla's number a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S ENTIRE CONDO
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the HISS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gas could have slowly filled the condo.  Seventeen-hundred square feet with high ceilings, for days and days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack replaces the receiver.  He pockets Marla's number, d out a small FILOFAX.  He flips through the pages for phon numbers and addresses.  Most of the pages are blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many young people feel trapped and desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, the refrigerator's compressor could have clicked on... Click.  KABOOM!  SCREEN GOES WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks at the Doorman.  Tyler's BUSINESS CARD falls f the Filofax.  Jack catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't know what you want, you end up with a lot you don't. The Doorman walks away.  Jack stares at Tyler's card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you asked me now, I couldn't tell you why I called him. Jack re-deposits the quarter, dials Tyler's number.  It RINGS... and RINGS and RINGS.  Jack sighs and hangs up th phone.  A moment, then the phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... I'm sorry.  We met on the plane.  We had the same briefcase. I'm... you know, the clever guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just called a second ago.  There was no answer.  I'm at a payphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I star-sixty-nined you.  I never pick up my phone.  What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... let me see... here's the thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small building in the middle of a concrete parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Tyler sit in the back, with a pitcher of BEER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You buy furniture.  You tell yourself: this is the last sofa I'll ever need.  No matter what else happens, I've got the sofa issue handled.  Then, the right set of dishes.  The right dinette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is how we fill up our lives. Tyler lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, now it's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All gone. Tyler offers cigarettes.  Jack declines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be worse.  A woman could cut off your penis while you're asleep and toss it out the window of a moving car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's always that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, maybe I'm wrong.  Maybe it's a terrible tragedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, you did lose a lot of nice, neat little shit.  The trendy paper lamps, the Euro-trash shelving unit, am I right? Jack laughs, nods.  He shakes his head, drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But maybe, just maybe, you've been delivered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (toasts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delivered from Swedish furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delivered from armchairs in obscure green stripe patterns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delivered from Martha Stewart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delivered from bullshit colors like "Cobalt," "Ebony," and "Fuchsia." They laugh together.  Then, silence.  They drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Insurance'll cover it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, you gotta start making the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What list?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "now I get to go out and buy the exact same stuff all over again" list.  That list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't... think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time maybe get a widescreen TV. You'll be occupied for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I have to file a claim...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The things you own, they end up owning you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, it's late.  I should find a hotel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you called me up, because you just wanted to have a drink before you... go find a hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't follow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on our third pitcher of beer. Just ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called me so you could have a place to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you cut the shit and ask if you can stay at my place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would that be a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a problem for you to ask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I stay at your place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.  But, I want you to do me one favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to hit me as hard as you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to hit me as hard as you can. Freeze picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you a little bit about Tyler Durden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And we see it's PORNOGRAPHY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, in the foreground, FACES CAMERA.  In the BACKGROUND Tyler sits at a bench, looking at individual FRAMES cut f movies.  Near him, a PROJECTOR rolls film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler was a night person.  He sometimes worked as a projectionist. A movie doesn't come in one big reel, it's on a few.  In old theaters, two projectors are used, so someone has to change projectors at the exact second when one reel ends and another reel begins.  Sometimes you can see two dots on screen in the upper right hand corner... Tyler points to the side of OUR FRAME and the TWO DOTS briefly APPEAR ONSCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're called "cigarette burns."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called a "changeover."  The movie goes on, and nobody in the audience has any idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would anyone want this shitty job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It affords him other interesting opportunities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Like splicing single frames from adult movies into family films.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In reel three, right after the courageous dog and the snooty cag -- who have celebrity voices -- eat out of a garbage can, there's the flash of Tyler's contribution... In the AUDIENCE, CHILDREN suddenly start squirming, confused, looking at each other. A WOMAN abruptly stops sucking her soda straw, feeling vaguely terrible.  Her uncomfortable HUSBAND slowly leans back in his seat. Jack and Tyler watch from the projection booth window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-forty-eighth of a second.  That's how long it's up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one really knows that they've seen it. But they did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nice, big cock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only a hummingbird could have caught Tyler at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler moves around one of many tables, setting down SOUP BOWLS.  Jack stands in the same position, FACING CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler also worked as a banquet waiter at the luxurious Pressman Hotel. The GUESTS command the WAITERS with snaps of fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack turns and WE PAN to Tyler, standing by a CART with a giant SOUP TUREEN.  His hands are at his open fly and he' in position to piss into the soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the guerrilla terrorist of the food service industry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't watch.  I can't if you watch. Jack waits.  The SOUND of a STREAM of LIQUID is HEARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Oh, yeah.  Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He farted on meringue; he sneezed on braised endive; and, with creme of mushroom soup, well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.  Say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler and Jack come out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, either.  I want to find out.  I've never been hit, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  That's a good thing, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to die without any scars.  How much can you really know about yourself if you've never been in a fight?  Come on... you're the only person I've ever asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Jack stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not you?  I'm letting you go first.  Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, go crazy.  Let 'er rip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you want it?  In the face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surprise me. Jack swings a wide, clumsy roundhouse -- hits Tyler's neck -- makes a dull, flat sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  Sorry.  That didn't count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell.  That counted. Tyler shoots out a straight punch to Jack's chest.  Jack falls back against a car.  His eyes tear up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But a good strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've crossed the threshold.  You want to call it off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call what off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fight, pussy. Jack swings another roundhouse that slams right under Tyler's ear.  Tyler punches Jack in the stomach.  Tyler a Jack move clumsily, throwing punches.  They breathe heavi drooling saliva and blood, growing dizzier from every imp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Tyler sit on the curb, watching sparse headlight on the nearby freeway.  Their eyes are glazed with endorp induced serenity.  They look at each other, laugh.  Look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could fight anyone... one on one, whoever you wanted, who would you fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone. Jack thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My boss, probably. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would you fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad.  No question. A long pause as Jack studies Tyler's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know my dad.  Well, I knew him, till I was six.  He went and married another woman, had more kids. Every six years or so he'd do it again -- new city, new family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was setting up franchises.  My father never went to college, so it was really important that I go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After I graduated, I called him long distance and asked, "Now what?"  He said, "Get a job."  When I turned twenty-five, I called him and asked, "Now what?"  He said, "I don't know. Get married."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A generation of men raised by women. I'm wondering if another woman is the answer we really need. Another pause.  Jack feels his bleeding lip, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should do this again sometime. Tyler cracks a smile, give a sidelong glance to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A street sign: "PAPER STREET."  A PAPER MILL stis on one side, facing a lone HOUSE on the other.  The rest of the land is grass and weeds.  It's a grand, old three-story, long abandoned.  Tyler leads Jack toward it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how Tyler found the house, but he'd been there for half a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler leads Jack through the FRONT DOOR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looked like it was waiting to be torn down.  Most of the windows were boarded up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler and Jack climb CREAKY STAIRS to the 2ND FLOOR LANDI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of the doors locked.  The stairs were ready to collapse.  I didn't know if he owned it or he was squatting. Tyler opens the door to a ROOM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack enters, stis on the creaky BED.  Dust drifts upwards

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither would have surprised me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack turns on the water.  LOUD VIBRATIONS from the walls. Water spits in starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing worked.  The rusty plumbing leaked.  Turning on a light meant another light in the house went out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the tavern's lights are off.  Tyler and Jack FIGHT. FIVE GUYS stand around watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, his face showing NEW BRUISES AND CUTS, makes coffee with a wire-mesh strainer.  Tyler shuffles in, wearing a flannel bathrobe.  He spears pieces of bread on a fork, starts roasting them over a burner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were no neighbors.  Just warehouses and the paper mill.  The fart smell of steam, the hamster cage smell of wood chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits watching as Tyler SWINGS an old GOLF CLUB -- THWACK -- sends a golf ball soaring down the desolate str

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At night, Tyler and I were alone for half a mile in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the lights are off.  TEN GUYS YELL, standing around J and Tyler, who FIGHT.  THREE CARS are parked in the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits on basement stairs, watching as Tyler, knee-dee in water, works at an open FUSEBOX, flipping breakers in certain order, showing Jack how it's done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it rained, we had to kill the power.  By the end of the first month, I didn't care about TV.  I didn't mind the warm, stale refrigerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CANDLES BURN.  Tyler and Jack are seated across from each other on the buckled floor, reading MAGAZINES.  Rain DRIP from the ceiling.  No furniture.  THOUSANDS of MAGAZINES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The previous occupant had been a bit of a shut-in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of magazine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, a new riot control grenade... (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...the successful combination of concussive, 3000 foot-candle flash- blasts and simultaneous high-velocity disbursement of...blah, blah, blah..." Tyler begins RIPPING the ARTICLE from his magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("Reader's Digest")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I am Joe's Lungs."  It's written in first person.  "Without me, Joe could not take in oxygen to feed his red blood cells."  There's a whole series -- "I am Joe's Prostate."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I get cancer, and I kill Joe." Tyler tosses his article in a pile of other articles, chooses another magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you reading?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldier of Fortune.  Business Week. New Republic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show-off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the lights are off.  Jack and Tyler stand amidst FIFT GUYS around TWO GUYS FIGHTING.  The crowd YELLS MORE WILD than before.  In the background are EIGHT PARKED CARS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have been haggling with my insurance company.  I should have been looking for a new condo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack walks along.  He stops, looking at a CHURCH with SUPPORT-GROUP-PEOPLE milling around the entrance, drinkin coffee and sodas.  Marla's there, amongst them, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .... I should have been upset about my nice, neat, flaming little shit. Jack's face shows no reaction.  He continues to walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, in work clothes, interlocks his fingers and POPS hi knuckles, picks up a saucepan with coffee and sips.  Tyle in waiter's uniform, comes to have Jack straighten his ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the week, we were Ozzie and Harriet. Jack picks up his briefcase and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Wednesday night, ever Wednesday night...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the lights are off.  No one around, but there are at least TWENTY-FIVE CARS parked in the full lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we were finding something out: we were finding out, more and more, that we were not alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SLIDE SHOW progresses, run by a chipper salesman, WALTE Jack sits, deadpan, with a PUFFY LIP and a BRUISED cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thursday mornings, all I could do was think about next week. Boss gives Jack a dubious look.  Walter's next SLIDE: a COMPUTER SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The basic premise of cyber-netting your office is -- make things more efficient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get the icon in cornflower blue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Walter continues, his sales pitch drowned out by Jack's V

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter, the Microsoft account exec. Walter, with his smooth, soft hands. Maybe he was thinking about the free- range potluck he'd been to last weekend, or his church-group car-wash fund-raiser.  Or, probably not. Walter moves to Jack and slaps him in the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I showed this already to my man here. You liked it, didn't you? Jack smiles.  His teeth are RED with BLOOD.  They GLOW eerily in the dim light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can swallow a pint of blood before you get sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I'd hate to see what happened to the other guy. Jack keeps the smile frozen on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw Walter.  His candy-ass wouldn't last a second Wednesday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of silent darkness, HEADLIGHTS appear from all directions.  CARS PULL UP and park in the already-packed lot.  YOUNG MEN get out and march into the tavern...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men, including Jack and Tyler, enter and stand agains the back wall, waiting.  The bartender, IRVINE, calls out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink up people.  We're closing. Irvine flicks on the LIGHTS.  Drunken customers squint an get the message.  They plop down money, leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was right in everyone's face. Tyler and I just made it visible. Irvine hits a button and the JUKEBOX loses power.  Member of the waiting army begins to share secret looks.  Finall one buy locks the door.  Two other guys close the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was on the tip of everyone's tongue.  Tyler and I just gave it a name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BOMB-SHELTER.  Concrete walls.  One BARE BULB above, Ty standing directly beneath it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to fight club. The guys mill around, finding partners.  Everyone brims w eagerness, but tries to act cool.  CHATTER gets LOUDER. Everyone spreads out, forming a circle, Tyler at center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every week, Tyler gave the rules that he and I decided. PEAKING CHATTER, till Tyler raises his arms and the CHATT DIES.  A couple of COUGHS, FEET SHUFFLING, then, SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first rule of fight club is -- you don't talk about fight club.  The second rule of fight club is -- you don't talk about fight club.  The third rule of fight club is -- when someone says "stop" or goes limp, the fight is over.  Fourth rule is -- only two guys to a fight.  Fifth rule -- one fight at a time.  Sixth rule -- no shirts, no shoes.  Seventh rule -- fights go on as long as they have to.  And the eighth and final rule -- if this is your first night at fight club, you have to fight. Tyler steps back.  A short guy, RICKY, and a GOATEED MAN take off shirts and shoes and step to the center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This kid, Ricky -- supply clerk -- couldn't remember whether you ordered pens with blue ink or black ink ... The two fighters circle, then begin throwing PUNCHES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Ricky was a god for ten minutes last week when he trounced an actuary twice his size. Harder, faster PUNCHES between the two.  SWEAT flies. SHOUTS become DEAFENING.  Ricky's getting the best of Goateed Man, POUNDING him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes all you could hear were flat, hard packing sounds over the yelling, or the wet choke when someone caught their breath and sprayed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spittle-lipped)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssssstop... !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, eating lunch, watches the BROKEN-NOSED WAITER with GOATEE -- from the above fight -- converse with a MAITRE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if I could tell someone they had a good fight, I wouldn't be talking to the same man. The Goateed Waiter approaches Jack and sets a refill soda down on the table.  The two of them briefly make eye cont

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you were in fight club is not who you were in the rest of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands over a copy machine, hit by flashes of light. He glances over his shoulder, watches Ricky, wearing an apron, push a supply cart.  Ricks nods at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't alive anywhere like you were there.  But fight club only exists in the hours between when fight club starts and when fight club ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, playing SOLITAIRE on his computer, daubs blood from his mouth with a handkerchief.  Boss, passing by the doorway, looks in at Jack, irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you getting yourself into every week? Jack keeps playing Solitaire.  Boss enters, folds his arm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After fight club, everything else in your life gets the volume turned down.  You can deal with anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you finished those reports?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him reports)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people who had power over you have less and less. Jack looks at Boss.  Reflexively, Jack's tongue plays wit his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By this point, I could wiggle most of the teeth in my jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler and Jack walk, both smoking cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy came to fight club for the first time, his ass was a wad of cookie dough.  After a few weeks, he was carved out of wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you could fight any celebrity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alive or dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hemingway.  You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shatner.  William Shatner. They reach a BUS STOP as a BUS arrives, tossing their cigarettes, getting on board...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus is crowded.  As Tyler and Jack walk toward the ba Jack studies the faces of OTHER PASSENGERS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all started seeing things differently.  Wherever we went. They hold hand grips.  Jack looks up at an ADVERTISEMENT; CALVIN KLEIN ad featuring a tan, bare-chested MUSCLE STUD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I felt sorry for all the guys packing into gyms, trying to look like what Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger said they should. Tyler looks at Jack, looks at the C.K. advertisement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Self-improvement is masturbation. Self-destruction is the answer. A MAN in a suit KNOCKS Tyler's shoulder as he passes.  Th Man takes a handle, close by.  Jack's pissed, staring at man, who stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tyler, so the Man can hear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could take him. Tyler looks to Jack, glances over his shoulder at the Man Tyler casually picks a small scab off Jack's nostril.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trick is not to care. Tyler stares forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler HITS the floor, stomach first.  HIS OPPONENT lands top of him, grappling, trying for a CHOKE HOLD.  The surrounding CROWD, Jack included, SCREAMS at them... Tyler and the Opponent wrestle desperately, and Tyler fli his attacker, gets on top, sprawling to pin him.  Tyler turns -- starts reining PUNCHES into the Opponent's GROIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack lands a couple of BLOWS to HIS OPPONENT'S stomach -- brings up a left uppercut that smashes the Opponent's jaw Tiny spatters of BLOOD adorn the walls, along with sweat. Jack catches sight of a swollen-faced Tyler, watching appreciatively, a smile growing slowly on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fight club wasn't about winning or losing.  It wasn't about words. The Opponent recovers, throws a headlock on Jack.  Jack snakes his arm into a counter headlock.  They wrestle lik wild animals.  The crowd CHEERS maniacally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hysterical shouting was in tongues, like at a Pentecostal church. Onlookers kneel to stay with the fight, cheering LOUDER. The Opponent SMASHES Jack's head to the floor, over and o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... stop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the fight was over, nothing was solved, but nothing mattered. Everyone moves in as the Opponent steps away.  Tyler push through the crowd.  Others lift Jack up.  They turn their attention to the floor, to a BLOOD MASK of Jack's face -- similar to the TEAR MASK on BOB'S SHIRT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool. Jack limply shakes his Opponent's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about next week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me.  How about next month? Everyone helps Jack walk.  He's sweating, bleeding, smili

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afterwards, we all felt saved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NURSE tends to Jack while Tyler watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fell down some stairs. The Nurse doesn't look at Tyler, just keeps tending to Ja

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fell down some stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes Tyler spoke for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler and Jack share the cracked MIRROR.  Tyler's clippin at his hair with blunt, ill-suited SCISSORS.  Jack's brushing his teeth, spitting out pink foam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fight club became the reason to cut your hair short and trim your fingernails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any historical figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... Ghandi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abe Lincoln.  Big reach.  Skinny guys fight till they're burger. Jack reaches in his mouth, exploring, pulls -- yanks a TOOTH.  Jack looks at it.  Tyler puts scissors down, done

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, even the Mona Lisa's falling apart. Jack drops the tooth in the sink with Tyler's hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack enters, buttoning his shirt.  The PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? INTERCUT WITH...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla's in the HALL, on the PAYPHONE, twisting the phone cord around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been the last few weeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla? Jack looks through the archway and sees Tyler, in his gum flannel bathrobe, doing sit-ups.  Jack leans, cups the ph

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forwarding number.  I haven't seen you at any support groups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the idea -- we split them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't been going to yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found a new one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's for men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like testicular cancer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, this is a bad time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been going to debtor's anonymous.  You want to see some truly fucked up people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just on my way out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.  I got a stomach full of Xanax.  I took what was left of a bottle.  Might've been too much. Jack looks exasperated, turns TO LOOK INTO THE CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picture yourself watching Marla Singer throw herself around her crummy apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't a for-real suicide thing. This is probably one of those cry-for- help things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This could go on for hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're staying in tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to wait to hear me describe death? Jack puts the handset on top of the phone, still off the hook, walks out the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to listen and see if my spirit can use the telephone? Thru the archway: Tyler leans to look in, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRUNTS of PLEASURE and EXERTION.  Glimpses of TORSOS, ASS LEGS, ARMS, BREASTS, and FEMALE HAIR, all DRENCHED in SWE Sheets RIP.  Bodies hit the FLOOR.  Insane GRUNTING and LAUGHING.  A flash of MARLA'S FACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits up in bed, looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack steps out of his room.  The neighboring door is clos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler's door was closed.  I'd been living here two months, and Tyler's door was never closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stares into the TOILER, looking at SIX USED CONDOMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits at the table, sips coffee, read Reader's Digest He hears FOOTSTEPS approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to believe what I dreamt last night. Marla walks in, straightening her dress, looks like she's been raped by a hurricane.  Jack's jaw drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hardly believe anything about last night. Marla goes to pour coffee.  She takes a swig, GARGLES and SPITS it in the sink.  She gives Jack a lascivious smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here? Marla stares at him a beat, then drops the cup in the sin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Marla shoves open the door to the backyard and walks out. Jack gets up, watches her stomp away. Jack turns and -- Tyler is at his shoulder, staring after Marla.  He's in his usual sweatpants.  He grins at Jack, then moves away, pours himself coffee.  Jack, smoldering, slumps at the table and picks up Reader's Digest.  Tyler puts his foot on a countertop, does stretching exercises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a piece of work.  Get this -- I come in here last night, the phone's off the hook... Jack pretends to read, quickly glances at Tyler.  TYLER'S VOICE FADES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already knew the story before he told it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler enters, gently lifts the handset and listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from handset)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you when I'm floating out of my body. Tyler smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could Tyler, off all people, think it was a bad thing that Marla Singer was about to die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tyler, a wry smile on his face, ambles up the stiars, looking at the rotting walls.  He reaches the top of the stairs and heads for Marla's room.  Before he can knock, Marla's hand shoots out and grabs him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marla pulls Tyler inside and shuts the door.  Her drugged eyes look him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got here fast. She staggers and sits on the bed.  She slides off, along with the blanket and sheets, to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mattresses are all sealed in slippery plastic. She tries to focus her eyes on Tyler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
